category.term: 2361~Jamie Pressly~I Hate My Teenage Daughter~Katie Finneran~FOX Broadcasting Company
category.label: InformQString

content.div:
"I can't believe I have to go on the computer to find out what's going on with my kids," Katie Finneran's character says in an early scene in I Hate My Teenage Daughter, one of the most divisive new sitcoms to bow since a little show called Married with Children.

Finneran and Jamie Pressly play single mothers and best friends fearful that their snarky, over-indulged 14-year-old daughters are turning into the mean girls who used to pick on them when they were that age. Later in the episode, when Pressly's character confiscates her daughter's cellphone so they can have a family night together with no distractions, her daughter cries, "This is how horror movies start."

In person, Pressly -- who herself was picked on by the mean girls in school, when she was growing up in North Carolina -- is only too happy to play the hateful mom. In the cult TV comedy My Name Is Earl, Pressly played the eponymous Earl's ex-wife and the show's main antagonist, a self-centred, vain, manipulative schemer.

Her character in I Hate My Teenage Daughter may be a little smoother 'round the edges, but she's still a schemer by nature.

"First out," Pressly said, "it's fun to play the bitch. Ask me. It's fun."

Pressly agreed to play a post-adolescent mother following a phone call from the head of Teenage Daughter's producing studio.

"(He) called me and said, 'I've got something for you,'" Pressly recalled. "He said, 'Screw all these other ones. This is the show.' I said, 'What's it called?' He said, 'I Hate My Teenage Daughter.' I said, 'I'll see you tomorrow. It sounds good to me.'

"It's really something you say under your breath. It's one of those points where they just drive you to the edge and you just want to throw them, so you're, like, 'God, I hate my teenage daughter.' You don't really. You love them dearly, of course. But every parent has that moment when they want to break down and just scream. It's not like this is something nobody's heard of, or not been through before."

Early reviews have been unkind, but as Married with Children showed, reviewers sometimes get it wrong.

Pressly and Finneran's characters are living vicariously through their daughters. They're taking the opportunity to relive their own high-school experiences, in a "do-over" of their own teen years. At the same time, they're determined to provide their daughters with the kind of childhood they only dreamt of when they were young. They want to be good parents, to build their daughters' self-esteem and put their daughters' happiness and well-being above their own, but it's not working out the way they expected.

Teenage Daughter has had a lot of time to get the beats right. It premieres Nov. 30 on FOX and Global TV, and is the last of the major fall network series to debut before the mid-season rush in January.

Nearly everyone can relate to the pitfalls of parenthood, Pressly insists. You don't have to be a parent with a teenage daughter to "get" Teenage Daughter.

"You can be a divorcee," Pressly said. "You can be a single parent. You can be the sister or brother of a teenage ass. Everyone, whether they're married or divorced or have children or don't have children, they were children once. I was that difficult 14-year-old. I think this is just one of those shows where, for 30 minutes, everybody, especially parents, are going to be able to sit down and realize they're not alone, that they're not the only ones in the hormone hell that they're in with their children."

Hindsight is 20/20, Pressly believes, where raising children is concerned. The trouble with wisdom is that it's hard to see at the time, when you're in the middle of something.

"You don't know, as a parent, when you're in the middle of it, what you're supposed to do or how to handle it," Pressly said. "Kids these days have so much technology and are so much smarter than we were. They're talking over our head and Googling and tweeting and doing all these things. So, seeing this show and seeing two people who have no idea how to do any of that, is cathartic, in a way. They couldn't be further from their daughters, as far as popularity goes, or pretty clothes or technology. We were complete opposites, when we were that age."

At its heart, I Hate My Teenage Daughter is a show about best friends, Finneran believes.

"And everybody's got a best friend," she said. "I think."

I Hate My Teenage Daughter premieres Nov. 30 on FOX and Global at 9:30 p.m. ET/PT.

entry.title: Fall TV 2011 Preview: The 10 Best New Shows

link.Abstract: We've narrowed it down to the 10 most promising new shows of the season.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract:
It's that time of year again -- time to finally give up on all those well-intentioned attempts to enjoy the great outdoors, and relinquish every spare moment to the sweet, sweet boob tube. Grab some snacks, settle into your couch's butt groove and get ready to face the new season with Dose.ca's guide to Fall TV.

While there are no obvious breakout shows this year, there are a few that have the potential to avoid cancellation and win a weekly slot on our PVR. We've narrowed it down to the 10 most promising new shows of the season.

-Jen McDonnell/Dose.ca
